head.title: A Social Contract, An Officer's Duty

hedline.hl1: A Social Contract, An Officer's Duty

abstract.p: Benjamin B Tucker letter on July 6 editorial on recent assaults in Central Park says police need continuing in-service training on gender relations and gender violence

block.p: I agree with your contention that the police need more intensive training on issues of gender relations and gender-related violence (editorial, July 6).

I would suggest, however, that police reaction to recent assaults in Central Park reflects another of the deep-rooted issues that continue to erode public confidence in the police. While better entry-level training for police is clearly needed, continuing in-service training should be required for all members of the department at every level.
I agree with your contention that the police need more intensive training on issues of gender relations and gender-related violence (editorial, July 6).

I would suggest, however, that police reaction to recent assaults in Central Park reflects another of the deep-rooted issues that continue to erode public confidence in the police. While better entry-level training for police is clearly needed, continuing in-service training should be required for all members of the department at every level.

The training should reinforce the notion that those who take the oath to serve have a duty to conduct themselves as professionals. We need a continuing commitment to changing both the formal and informal socialization processes that influence the conduct of our police. As a former New York City cop, I believe that the social contract between the public and the police requires nothing less.
BENJAMIN B. TUCKER New York, July 6, 2000
The writer is associate professor and criminal justice coordinator at Pace University.
